body:
To the Editor:

Re “Unions Subdued, Walker Turns to Tenure at Wisconsin Colleges” (front page, June 5):

It is unfortunate and sad that academic freedom is being trammeled at the University of Wisconsin, where tenure and shared governance are under attack.

On the Madison campus is a plaque that states one of the university’s tenets: “Whatever may be the limitations which trammel inquiry elsewhere, we believe the great State University of Wisconsin should ever encourage that continual and fearless sifting and winnowing by which alone the truth can be found.” In the 1890s the university was pressured to censure a professor accused of being a pro-union radical, and the Board of Regents’ response is on that plaque.

The state capital is less than a mile from the university campus, and there has always been animosity toward the liberal faculty and students. Gov. Scott Walker showed how much he values college education when he became a college dropout, and he is showing it again with his politically motivated proposal that shows disdain toward the university. THOMAS J. STRAKA

Pendleton, S.C.

The writer is an alumnus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison and a forestry professor at Clemson University in South Carolina.
description: An alumnus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison criticizes proposals by Wisconsin’s governor that affect tenure and governance.
title: Letter: Gov. Scott Walker and the University of Wisconsin
